Acura 3.2TL slightly upgraded.

Restyled for last year, the Acura 3.2TL enters 2000 with only a few enhancements such as a new five-speed automatic transmission with SportShift and a new air bag system. The engine has also been massaged for quicker off-the-line acceleration and improved fuel economy.

Although 2000 doesn't signal sweeping changes for this automobile Acura refers to as its ultimate performance sedan, it obviously isn't resting on its laurels either.

While Acura enjoyed about an 8 percent year-over-year sales increase in 1999, the TL was up more than 80 percent. This is even more remarkable when the rather flat sales performance of some of TL's closest competitors is taken into consideration.

With its $29,000 price tag and staggering list of standard equipment, the 3.2TL is an easy sedan to buy on several levels. In the near- or entry-luxury segment, the TL stands out as a real value.

A key factor in the ease of purchase is not having to make too many decisions. If you want to make your head swim, try buying a full-size pickup truck where nearly everything is an option. Buying a TL is the antithesis of that experience. Engine, there is only one: a zesty 3.2-liter V-6. Transmission? There is only one of those, too. It is a five-speed automatic/manual that Acura calls its Sequential SportShift.

At 225 horsepower and 216 foot-pounds of peak torque, the key engine statistics haven't changed from last year; but Acura claims the 0-60 mph time has been trimmed by about half a second. This was achieved primarily through enhancements to the engine's breathing system. I found the new TL took just over seven seconds to reach 60 mph from a standing stop. A bit less thirsty than last year's version, the new TL has earned a miles-per-gallon rating of 19 city and 29 highway.

Perched upon 16-inch tires, the fully independent suspension does an impressive job of soaking up broken pavement. With the emphasis on ride quality, handling is a bit of a compromise, but cornering is predictable and without theatrics. Wonderfully agile, the TL zips around the city with ease. A traction system is standard, and it operates at speeds below 25 mph, controlling wheel spin through the anti-lock brakes. Disc brakes on all four wheels bring the TL to sure-footed stops.

Comfortably spacious, the cabin is characterized by clean, simple lines. A number of subtle colors and textures add some interest to this interior. A little leather, a little wood grain, it all meshes together into a functional and handsome cockpit. Everything is easy to see, and for the most part, operate.

My test Acura had the one factory-installed option. It's the Global Positioning System navigation with its screen positioned above the audio system controls. It also serves as the control center for the ventilation system, and here is where things get a little complicated. Once set, however, the climate control is good to go and probably won't have to be messed with anyway.

The seats are comfortable, and there is sufficient legroom for rear seat passengers. Likewise, cargo space is in ample supply and the bumper-high lift-over is a real plus. A credit to the narrow A- and C-pillars, visibility is excellent in all directions. Front side-impact air bags join the dual front air bags in supplying passive restraint. While the TL competes in the entry-luxury segment, its interior bespeaks a more expensive sedan.

Base price of the Acura 3.2TL is $28,855. When opting for the navigational system, it is included into the sticker price, adding $1,545 to the total. The base price with navigational system is $30,400.

Included in this price and not already mentioned: height-adjustable front shoulder belts, high-intensity-discharge headlamps, dual power remote outboard mirrors, rear-window defroster, leather seating, leather-wrapped tilt steering wheel, eight-way power driver's seat, four-way power passenger seat, heated front seats, five-speaker Bose AM/FM stereo/cassette/compact disc player, redundant steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, speed-sensing intermittent wipers, power moon roof, auto day/night rearview mirror, auto-off headlamps, outside temperature gauge, power windows/door locks, keyless remote entry, anti-theft security system with electronic engine immobilizer and 16-inch alloy wheels. Adding the $455 delivery charge brought the price as tested to $30,855.

Heaps, Russ
The Washington Times
April 28, 2000
